The first set related
to initial exposure, the amount of initial exposure.

How does that relate
to the chances that you would unfollow someone?

It could go in one of two ways. So the first one
was what we refer to as reversion hypothesis.

This is capturing
the-- maybe the idea that misinformation exposure
can be self-correcting.

So the more you're exposed
to misinformation at time T1, the more likely you are going
to be to unfollow at time T2.

So that's maybe the positive
story if we see that.

And this could happen for a
number of different reasons. It could be high redundancy.

The misinformation
spreaders you follow, each one has a
smaller marginal gain.

So then it might be that
they become redundant and there's maybe
information overload and that might be a reason why
you might be seeing unfollowing.

Or it might be that
maybe your initial choice in following a misinformation
spreader was not intentional.

It wasn't related to your desire
to consume this information. And the more you have
of them, the more

you get exposed to that, you
will have sort of regression to the mean or going back
to your less exposed self.

The other way this could
go is self-imposing.

Misinformation exposure
being self-imposing, what we refer to as the
inertia hypothesis, which is that the higher
exposure at time T1

is associated with lower
unfollowing at time T2. So this could be-- again,
due to many reasons.

It could be that high
exposure at time T1 can be a consequence
of selective exposure,

like you are seeking
out what ask. Researchers and fact
checkers normatively

decided as misinformation, and
therefore, it's an indication

that you have demand for it. And there's studies that

more you follow misinformation

spreaders, the more exposed

basically the cause
